Hello gang â€” some help with some research please! Iâ€™m looking for the best stack to run a public API. Like, as a developer, what would make you go: oh, thatâ€™s good documentation; oh thatâ€™s an auth key designed by someone who knows what theyâ€™re doing; this is really straightforward onboarding, etc. Are there any examples of startups doing this in a really great way?

Reason being that I had <https://twitter.com/genmon/status/1636698753007603713|a project slightly blow up on Twitter> over the weekend, and Iâ€™m thinking about providing a back-end service and kits (so people can make their own kits too). Just assessing options rn.

Thank you!

attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/genmon|@genmon>: I made an AI clock for my bookshelves! It composes a new poem every minute using ChatGPT and mysteriously has this enthusiastic vibe which I am totally into <https://www.instagram.com/p/Cp44-AMNyd9/>

text:
Hello! I saw that tweet and thought it was awesome :-)

Iâ€™ve been wondering about the same thing lately - the best way to host (and monetize!) an API. Perhaps because Iâ€™m not the greatest designer and APIs come more naturally to me, and also because Iâ€™ve read the recent posts about LangChain / ReAct and it makes me think that creating APIs for LLM use might be a great business model - like the old saying, youâ€™d be selling shovels in a gold rush, rather than doing the shovelling yourself.
Anyway I think perhaps something like <https://cloud.google.com/apigee> might be good? It seems to me that when creating APIs, the code / logic is easy (and fun, and what you want to concentrate on)â€¦ and itâ€™s everything else thatâ€™s hard, the admin and ops of authenticating users, rate limiting, stopping abuse, charging usersâ€¦ Thatâ€™s what Apigee seems to be solving for.

attachments.fallback: Google Cloud: Apigee API Management Â |Â  Google Cloud
attachments.text: Apigee, part of Google Cloud, helps leading companies design, secure, and scale application programming interfaces (APIs). Try Apigee for free.

Youâ€™re completely right about wanting to do the tedious management bit. Iâ€™ll have a look at Apigee, thanks! Do you know what itâ€™s like from a developer perspective, like somebody making use of the API?

text: jumping on a train of discussion with small delay, I wrote an app that actually have immutable notes, but you can edit the note by supplying correct version of a text afterwards, so you have all the versions of your note in the end, here it is <https://webpad.com.ua|https://webpad.com.ua>
